revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=August 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2017}} {{Infobox person |name = Sir Gervase Helwys |image = Gervase.jpg |image_size = 200px |caption = |birth_name = Gervase Helwys |birth_date = 1 September 1561 |birth_place = [[Saundby]], Nottinghamshire, England |death_date = 20 November 1615 |death_place = [[Tower Hill]], [[Westminster]] |body_discovered = |death_cause = [[Hanging]] |resting_place = [[The Tower of London]], [[Westminster]] |resting_place_coordinates = |residence = [[Tower of London]] |nationality = [[Kingdom of England|English]] |ethnicity = |citizenship = |other_names = Gervase Helwysse
Jervis Yelwys |known_for = Complicity in murder of [[Thomas Overbury|Sir Thomas Overbury]] |education = [[Middle Temple]] |alma_mater = [[New Inn Hall|New Inn]] |employer = [[Henry Howard, 1st Earl of Northampton]] |occupation = [[Lieutenant of the Tower of London]] |years_active = |home_town = |title = Sir |salary = |networth = |height = |weight = |term = |predecessor = |successor = |party = |opponents = [[Sir Edward Coke]]
[[Sir Francis Bacon]] |boards = |religion = |spouse = Mary Brooke |partner = |children = William
Thomas
Nathaniel Gervase John
Elizabeth Bridget
Maria
Jane
Anna
Francesca |parents = John Helwys
Mary Blagden |relations = [[Thomas Helwys]] |callsign = |signature = |website = |footnotes = }} '''Sir Gervase Helwys''' (1 September 1561 – 20 November 1615), also known as '''Jervis Yelwys''', was a [[Lieutenant of the Tower of London]] found guilty of complicity in the murder of Sir [[Thomas Overbury]] and hanged in 1615. The scandal provoked much public and literary conjecture and irreparably tarnished [[James I of England|King James I]]'s court with an image of corruption and depravity. There are variations in the spelling of Helwys: Helwis, Helwiss, Helewyse, Helwysse, Yelwys, Ellowis, Elwys, Elwis, Elvis, Elwes, and Elwaies.{{cite web|url=http://www.nottshistory.org.uk/articles/villagepacks/broxtowehall.htm|title=Nottinghamshire history > Articles > Broxtowe Hall|publisher=nottshistory.org.uk}} ==Background== Gervase Helwys was born on 1 September 1561 in [[Saundby]], Nottinghamshire, the first child of parents John Helwys (1535–1600) and Mary Blagden of [[Thames Ditton]]. His cousin, [[Thomas Helwys]] (1575–1616), one of the joint founders, with John Smyth, of the [[Baptist]] denomination, was thrown into [[Newgate Prison]] by the king for libel, where he died in 1616. As a student Helwys studied law at [[Middle Temple]] after completing his studies at [[New Inn Hall|New Inn]], at the [[University of Oxford]]. His uncle, Geoffrey Helwys, a successful merchant, Alderman and Sheriff of London, was also a member of the Inn.{{Cite book |author=John Hutchinson |date=1 January 2003 |title=A Catalogue of Notable Middle Templars: With Brief Biographical Notices |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Fw-3QC98d_UC&pg=PA117 |accessdate=2013-08-27 |publisher=The Lawbook Exchange, Ltd. |isbn=978-1-58477-323-8 |pages=117–}} Soon after, he married Mary Brooke, daughter of Thomas Brooke of [[Norfolk]]. On 7 May 1603, Helwys was knighted by King James I. A decade later, on 6 May 1613, he was appointed by the same king as [[Lieutenant of the Tower of London]] after being recommended to the post by [[Henry Howard, 1st Earl of Northampton]].{{cite DNB|wstitle=Howard, Henry (1540-1614)|volume=28|page=31}} As was common practice at the time, Helwys had to pay for the title, in this instance £2,000; £1,400 going to Northampton and £300 to [[Sir Thomas Monson, 1st Baronet|Sir Thomas Monson]], Master of the Armory in the Tower and a friend of Helwys'."Sir William Waad, Lieutenant of the Tower, and the Gunpowder Plot" by Fiona Bengtsen; Victoria, B.C.: Trafford, 2005 Whilst there, Helwys had been involved on 10 March 1614 in the "examination" of prisoner Edmond Peacham, a rector of [[Hinton St George|Hinton St. George]] who had been charged with having written a libel against the king,{{cite DNB|wstitle=Peacham, Edmond|volume=44|page=132}} at the request of the king's [[Attorney general]], [[Sir Francis Bacon]].''"The letters and the life of Francis Bacon including all his occasional works: namely letters, speeches, tracts, state papers, memorials, devices and all authentic writings not already printed among his philosophical, literary, or professional works"'' by Francis Bacon; James Spedding. London: Longman, Green, Longman, and Roberts, 1861–1874. ==Overbury Affair== [[File:Sir thomas overbury.jpg|left|thumbnail|150px|Portrait of [[Sir Thomas Overbury]] by Renold Elstracke, c. 1615-1616]] When his [[Secretary of State (England)|Secretary of State]], the [[Robert Cecil, 1st Earl of Salisbury|Earl of Salisbury]], died in 1612, the king had the notion of governing in person as his own chief Minister of State, with his young [[Scottish people|Scottish]] favourite, [[Robert Carr, 1st Earl of Somerset|Robert Carr]] carrying out many of Salisbury's former duties. But James's inability to attend closely to official business exposed the government to factionalism.Willson, pp 334–5. The Howard party, consisting of Henry Howard; [[Thomas Howard, 1st Earl of Suffolk]]; his son-in-law [[William Knollys, 1st Earl of Banbury]]; [[Charles Howard, 1st Earl of Nottingham]], and [[Thomas Lake|Sir Thomas Lake]], soon took control of much of the government and its patronage. Even the powerful Carr, hardly experienced for the responsibilities thrust upon him and often dependent on his intimate friend Overbury for assistance with government papers,Willson, p 349; Perry, p 105. fell into the Howard camp. He had done this after beginning an affair with the married [[Frances Carr, Countess of Somerset|Frances Howard, Countess of Essex]], daughter of the Earl of Suffolk, whom James assisted in securing an annulment of her marriage to free her to marry Carr.Lindley, p 120. Seeing as Overbury distrusted the Howards and still had Carr's ear, he tried to prevent the marriage. To remove him from court, the Howard faction manipulated Overbury into seeming to be disrespectful to the [[Anne of Denmark|queen]]. Then it was no small feat to persuade the king to offer Overbury an assignment as ambassador to the court of Tsar [[Michael of Russia]], with the Howards being fully aware that his refusal would be seen as tantamount to treason. The plan worked and Overbury declined, sensing the urgency to remain in England and at his friend's side. On 22 April 1613, Overbury was placed in the Tower at the king's "request",Willson, p 342. eventually dying there five months later on 15 September "of natural causes.” In July 1615, after rumours began circulating at court, it subsequently emerged that Overbury had in fact been poisonedLindley, p 146; Barroll, Anna of Denmark, p 136.{{cite web|url=https://archive.org/stream/journalofsirroge00wilbrich/journalofsirroge00wilbrich_djvu.txt|title=Full text of "The journal of Sir Roger Wilbraham, solicitor-general in Ireland and master of requests, for the years 1593–1616, together with notes in another hand, for the years 1642–1649"|publisher=archive.org}} the discovery of the crime being revealed by a boy in the employment of one of the apothecaries responsible.{{cite web|url=https://archive.org/stream/toweroflondon00benhuoft/toweroflondon00benhuoft_djvu.txt|title=Full text of 'The Tower of London'|publisher=archive.org}} Investigations were made and proofs were abundantly forthcoming. At a dinner in [[Whitehall]] with the king's new Secretary of State, [[Ralph Winwood|Sir Ralph Winwood]], Helwys admitted that he suspected there might have been some foul play.''"The court of King James the First"'' by Godfrey Goodman, pp. 143 He immediately became suspect after correspondence surfaced between himself and Northampton concerning Overbury's conduct and health. In his letters to Helwys Northampton wrote with contempt of Overbury and expressed a desire that his own name should not be mentioned in connection with his imprisonment. Northampton also introduced one of the royal physicians, [[John Craig (physician)|John Craig]], to Helwys to report on the prisoner's health. Helwys also made the mistake of corresponding with Howard, the chief suspect in Overbury's poisoning.{{cite web|url=https://archive.org/stream/advicetoasonprec013268mbp/advicetoasonprec013268mbp_djvu.txt|title=Full text of 'Advice to a Son Precepts of Lord Burghley Sir Walter Raleigh And Francis Osborne'|publisher=archive.org}} When the matter was judicially investigated, Helwys felt his political enemies trying to credit him with a direct hand in the murder. On 1 October 1615, he was arrested and forced to exchange his lodgings for a cell in the Tower. ==Trial and execution== [[Image:Hollar, Vaclav - Poprava hrabete ze Straffordu.jpg|right|thumbnail|200px|Engraving depicting an execution at [[Tower Hill]] c. 1641]] In 1615, Helwys was put on trial, along with Monson, Richard Weston (the gaoler and ex-servant of Howard and Carr's), [[Mrs Anne Turner]] (widow of a fashionable London doctor), and a disreputable apothecary named James Franklin, in [[Guildhall, London|Guildhall]], London for complicity in the murder of Overbury. The hearings were presided over by [[Sir Edward Coke]], [[Lord Chief Justice of England and Wales|Lord Chief Justice of the King's Bench]], and Sir Francis Bacon. It was ruled that "poisons" had been "administered" in the form of "jellies" and "tarts" by Weston, Turner and Franklin at the direction of Frances Howard. When Howard and Carr were tried she admitted a part in the murder, but her husband did not. Fearing what Carr might say about him in court, James repeatedly sent messages to the Tower pleading with him to admit his guilt in return for a pardon. "It is easy to be seen that he would threaten me with laying an aspersion upon me of being, in some sort, accessory to his crime."Stewart, p 275. Carr refused and the couple were found guilty and sentenced to death. The king commuted their sentence to life imprisonment and they were eventually pardoned along with Monson. The only evidence against Helwys was that of Franklin, who asserted that the Lieutenant had been in league with Frances Howard. Through letters to Howard that were not read at the hearings, it was clear that Helwys initially had no idea that Overbury was being poisoned.{{cite web|url=http://www.ebooksread.com/authors-eng/andrew-bisset/essays-on-historical-truth-ssi/page-33-essays-on-historical-truth-ssi.shtml|title=Read the eBook Essays on historical truth by Andrew Bisset online for free (page 33 of 40)|first=Denis Larionov & Alexander|last=Zhulin|publisher=ebooksread.com}} He confessed later that he had entertained suspicions of this after discovering earlier attempts to poison Overbury on the part of the gaoler Weston, who had been placed in that position at the suggestion of Northampton. Considering the powerful people protecting Weston, and assuming him, indeed, to be no less than their agent, Helwys had hesitated to interfere in what seemed to him to be a matter of state. He had, however, done his utmost surreptitiously to save Overbury. It was plain both from Weston's statements and from Helwys' own, that the Lieutenant had done his very best to defeat the Turner-Essex-Northampton plot to poison his prisoner, throwing away the "rosalgar" and later "draughts", as well as substituting food for Overbury from his own kitchen for that "sent in" by Turner.{{Citation needed|date=April 2010}} He had made Weston recognise the "hideousness" of what he had done and made him promise to desist from further attempts upon the prisoner's life. Although Helwys maintained that he kept a close watch on Overbury after this event, he nevertheless suspected that the "thing was done" the moment his vigilance had been relaxed. On 18 November, – Helwys, Weston, Turner and Franklin – were found guilty as "accessories before the fact done" and, lacking powerful connections, were sentenced to death. On the day of his execution on the following Monday, 20 November at [[Tower Hill]],{{cite web|url=http://www.capitalpunishmentuk.org/tower.html |title=Confirmed executions at the Tower of London |publisher=capitalpunishmentuk.org |accessdate=2017-08-08}} Helwys gave an impassioned speech to the crowd in attendance protesting his innocence:
''I was so far from thinking myself foul in the fact, that until these two Gentlemen, (Doctor Felton and Doctor Whiting, the physicians for my soul) told me how deeply I had imbrued my hands in the blood of (Overbury) making me, by God’s law, as guilty in the concealing (of it) as if I had been a personal actor in it. Till then... I held myself ignorant of the deed, and my conscience so clear, that I did never ask God forgiveness...''''"The lieutenant of the Tower his speech and repentance, at the time of his death who was executed vpon Tower Hill, on the 20. day of Nouember, 1615 : together with a meditation and vow of his that hee made not long before he dyed"'' by Sir Gervase Helwys. Published in 1615, Printed by G. Eld for Na. Butter, and are to be sold at his shop neere Saint Austines Gate (London)
He did, however, beg God's forgiveness for both his guilt in the crime and for being “much addicted" to gambling. Helwys left behind him eight children with his wife Mary: William, Thomas, Nathaniel Gervase John, Elizabeth Bridget, Maria, Jane, Anna and Francesca.{{Cite book |year=1868 |title=Miscellanea Genealogica et Heraldica |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=cs4KAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA72 |accessdate=2013-08-27 |publisher=Hamilton, Adams, and Company |page=72}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Helwys, Gervase}} [[Category:1561 births]] [[Category:1615 deaths]] [[Category:Tower of London]] [[Category:People from Bassetlaw]] [[Category:16th-century English people]] [[Category:17th-century English people]] [[Category:People of the Tudor period]] [[Category:Lieutenants of the Tower of London]] [[Category:Executions at the Tower of London]] [[Category:Executed English people]] [[Category:People executed by the Kingdom of England by hanging]] [[Category:People executed by Stuart England]] [[Category:English politicians convicted of crimes]]

[[File:Royal Monogram of King Haakon VII of Norway.svg|thumb|200px|The monogram.]]
'''H7''' was the [[royal cypher]] of the Norwegian [[Monarchy of Norway|head of state]], [[Haakon VII of Norway|King Haakon VII]], who reigned from 1905 to 1957. When [[Operation Weserübung|Germany invaded Norway]] in 1940 as a part of [[World War II]], the [[Norwegian royal family|royal family]] fled the country and Haakon VII later spearheaded the Norwegian resistance in-exile in the [[United Kingdom]]. H7 became one of several symbols used by the [[Norwegian people|Norwegian populace]] to mark solidarity with and loyalty to the King, and adherence to the [[Norwegian resistance movement]].
==World War II== According to [[Minister of Foreign Affairs (Norway)|Minister of Foreign Affairs]] [[Bjørn Tore Godal]], speaking at the 50th anniversary for [[Victory in Europe Day]], Norway was the only country in which the initials of the head of state became a resistance symbol.<ref>{{cite news|title=Varm hyldning av motstandskongen|last=Grue|first=Øystein|date=8 May 1995|work=Aftenposten Aften|pages=3|language=Norwegian}}</ref> The monogram, with H superimposed on 7, was drawn on fences, walls, houses, roads, in the snow and otherwise in the public sphere.<ref>{{cite news|title=Det hendte|agency=Norwegian News Agency|date=26 July 2009|language=Norwegian}}</ref> It was also used in illegal art.<ref>{{cite news|title=Postkortet i våpenløs kamp mot den tyske okkupasjonsmakt|last=Lie|first=Wenche|date=23 December 1983|work=Aftenposten Aften|pages=3|language=Norwegian}}</ref> Coins with the H7 symbol were also attached to clothes.<ref name=kd94>{{cite book|title=Krigens dagbok|chapter=Hirden i sammestøt|page=94| editor=[[Per Voksø|Voksø, Per]] |publisher=Det Beste |location=Oslo |language=Norwegian |year=1984 |isbn=82-7010-166-4}}</ref> Such coins were confiscated by the Nazi authorities.<ref name=dahl>{{cite book|last=Dahl|first=Hans Fredrik|authorlink=Hans Fredrik Dahl|title="Dette er London". NRK i krig 1940–1945|publisher=Cappelen|location=Oslo|year=1978|pages=164–165|isbn=82-02-03929-0|language=Norwegian}}</ref> It was also used in the private sphere, among others on the inside of blinds.<ref>{{cite book|last=Nøkleby|first=Berit|author2=Ellingsen, Ane|authorlink=Berit Nøkleby|title=Norge i krig i bilder|publisher=Aschehoug|location=Oslo|date=209|page=233|isbn=978-82-03-23656-3|language=Norwegian}}</ref>
A symbol used in a similar way was the "V for victory", [[V sign#The V campaign and the victory/freedom sign|as popularised by Winston Churchill]]. However, the Axis attempted to usurp this sign, supposedly with the new meaning of "V for [[Victoria (mythology)|Viktoria]]".<ref>{{cite news|title=Ordmagikere|last=Eidem|first=Odd|authorlink=Odd Eidem|date=18 February 1984|work=Aftenposten Aften|pages=7|language=Norwegian}}</ref> While this campaign was successful in most of [[Nazi-occupied Europe]], it failed in Norway: Despite continued official use, the opposition also adopted the V-sign as an abbreviation of ''{{lang|de|verlieren}}'' (German for "to lose"), and filled in the Nazi V's with the H7 monogram.<ref>{{cite book|title=Folklore fights the Nazis: humor in occupied Norway, 1940-1945|first=Kathleen|last=Stokker|publisher=Univ of Wisconsin Press|year=1997|isbn=0-299-15444-0|pages=114–115}}</ref> In fact, this popularized the use of H7, which was soon drawn without the V.<ref name=dahl/>
The act of drawing or creating a H7 symbol in [[Occupation of Norway by Nazi Germany|German-occupied Norway]] was punishable by imprisonment.<ref>{{cite news|title=Meldinger fra Norge|last=Hjeltnes|first=Guri|authorlink=Guri Hjeltnes|date=7 April 2008|work=VG|pages=2|language=Norwegian}}</ref> Another possible sanction was terror from Nazi paramilitary groups, to which the police were ordered not to respond.<ref name=kd94/>
==Post-war use== The symbol was also evoked after World War II to have a commemorative effect, among others at the first post-war [[Holmenkollen ski jump|Holmenkollen ski jump event]], when the symbol was formed in large scale by people.<ref>{{cite news|title=Kongenes bakke og bakkenes konge|agency=Norwegian News Agency|date=11 March 1993|language=Norwegian}}</ref> It was also used on post-war coins.<ref>{{cite news|title=25.000 kroner for en 50-øre|last=Tagesen|first=Dan|date=13 September 2007|work=Stavanger Aftenblad|pages=|language=Norwegian}}</ref>
==Gallery== <gallery> File:Norway 1 Krone 1940 obverse H7 monogram.jpg|A 1940 [[Norwegian krone]] featuring the H7 monogram. File:Vær tro mot H7.jpg|Preserved H7 [[graffiti]] in [[Uranienborg, Norway|Uranienborg]], [[Oslo]]. File:Kronene i Håvet.JPG|Monograms carved in rock to mark royal visits to [[Kongsberg]] since 1623. H7 is on the second row, to the right. File:Votter med Håkon 7..jpg|Gloves featuring the H7 monogram </gallery>
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Norwegian monarchy]] [[Category:Political history of Norway]] [[Category:Cultural history of Norway]] [[Category:Norwegian resistance movement]] [[Category:Monograms]]

revision.comment: /* top */proper dab redirect, replaced: [[Lost Treasure (Magazine)|''Lost Treasure'']] → [[Lost Treasure (magazine)|''Lost Treasure'']] using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
{{Multiple issues| {{Tone|date=May 2017}} {{Refimprove|date=May 2017}} |section=yes}}
'''Lost mines''' are a popular form of lost [[treasure]] legend. The mine involved is usually of a high-value commodity such as [[gold]], [[silver]] or [[diamonds]]. Often there is a [[treasure map|map]] (sometimes called a "waybill") purportedly showing the location of the mine. Common reasons given for the mines being lost include: * The mine is discovered and worked by a recluse who refuses to divulge the location, and dies without revealing the location. * The mine is worked by native peoples who refuse to divulge the location to others. * The mineral deposit is discovered in a remote location, and upon returning to the area the discoverer cannot find it again. * The discoverer dies of hunger, thirst, or exposure shortly after discovering the deposit, and his body is found with rich ore specimens in his possession. * The discoverers are killed by hostile natives. Sometimes the natives cover up the entrance to the mine. * In Spanish colonies in the New World, many lost mines were supposedly worked under the direction of [[Jesuit]] priests before their [[Suppression of the Society of Jesus|sudden expulsion]] in 1767.
Some lost mine legends have a historical basis; some have none. But the lure of lost mine legends is attested by the many books on the subject, and the popularity of publications such as [[Lost Treasure (magazine)|''Lost Treasure'']] magazine.
==List of ''lost mine'' legends== Legends of lost mines are probably worldwide. Those listed below are just a sampling.
===Africa=== * [[King Solomon's Mines]]
===Australia=== * [[Lasseter's Reef]] (Never actually mined)
===Bolivia=== * [[Sacambaya mine]]
===Brazil=== * [[Muribeca mine]]
===Canada=== * [[Lost Lemon Mine]], [[Alberta]]<ref>{{cite news| url=http://archives.cbc.ca/science_technology/unexplained/clips/9708/ | work=CBC News}}</ref> * [[Pitt Lake gold find]], [[British Columbia]] * [[Jolly Jack's Lost Mine]], [[British Columbia]] * [[Lost McLeod Mine]], [[Northwest Territories]] * [[Johanssen's Lost Platinum Cache]], [[British Columbia]] * [[Foster's Lost Mine]], [[Vancouver Island]] * [[Lost Christie Lead]], [[British Columbia]] * [[Lost Silver Lead of Monashee Creek]], [[British Columbia]]
===Colombia=== * [[Chivor mine]], an emerald mine lost for 200 years, then found again.<ref>I. A. Mumme (1982) ''The Emerald'', Port Hacking, New South Wales: Mumme Publications, pp. 21–22.</ref>
===Mexico=== * Lost diamond mine of [[Vicente Guerrero]] * Lost [[Naranjal mine]], [[Durango]] * [[Planchas de Plata]], [[Sonora]], (sometimes called ''Bolas de Plata''). Periodically assumed to be "lost," although the location is well documented. * [[Tayopa]] silver mine, [[Sonora]]
===Russia=== * In the 19th century, gold fever was prevalent in the [[Ural (region)|Ural]] region near [[Ekaterinburg]]. There are many legends of the lost mines, for example in [[Mamin-Sibiryak]]'s stories. * There are many modern stories of lost diamond mines in the [[Sakha Republic|Yakutia]] region of north and northeast Russia
===United States=== * [[Lost Padre mine]], various locations in USA * [[Lost Cabin mine]], various locations in USA
====Arizona==== * [[Lost Dutchman's Gold Mine]], [[Arizona]] * [[Mine with the Iron Door]], Arizona
====California==== * [[Lost Pegleg mine]], [[California]]; supposedly found by mountain man [[Thomas L. Smith|"Pegleg" Smith]] * [[Lost Breyfogle mine]], California or [[Nevada]] * The [[Lost Cement Mine]], California * The [[Lost Dutch Oven Mine]], California * [[Death Valley Scotty]]'s secret mine, California or Nevada * [[Lost Gunsight mine]], California or Nevada
====Colorado==== * [[Lost Pin]], [[Delta County, Colorado]] * [[Recluse Goatherder's Gold Mine]], Colorado * [http://www.thegeozone.com/treasure/colorado/tales/co010a.jsp Three Skeletons, La Plata County, Colorado]
====Idaho==== * [[The Wheelbarrow Mine]], [[Idaho]]
====Kentucky==== * [[Swift's silver mine]], [[Kentucky]]
====Missouri==== * [[Yocum silver mine]], [[Stone County, Missouri]]
====Nevada==== * The [[Lost Sheepherders Mine]], Nevada
====New Mexico==== * [[Lost Adams Diggings]], [[New Mexico]] or Arizona
====Oregon==== * [[Lost Blue Bucket Mine]], [[Oregon]] * [[Two Frenchmen Mine]], [[Oregon]]

{{for|the silent romantic comedy|Manhattan (1924 film)}} {{Infobox film | name = Manhattan | image = Manhattan-poster01.jpg | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Woody Allen]] | producer = [[Charles H. Joffe]] | writer = Woody Allen
[[Marshall Brickman]] | starring = Woody Allen
[[Diane Keaton]]
[[Michael Murphy (actor)|Michael Murphy]]
[[Mariel Hemingway]]
[[Meryl Streep]]
[[Anne Byrne (actress)|Anne Byrne]] | music = [[George Gershwin]]
played by the [[New York Philharmonic]], [[Zubin Mehta]] and the [[Buffalo Philharmonic Orchestra|Buffalo Philharmonic]], [[Michael Tilson Thomas]] | cinematography = [[Gordon Willis]] | editing = [[Susan E. Morse]] | distributor = [[United Artists]] | released = {{Film date|1979|4|25}} | runtime = 96 minutes | country = United States | language = English | budget = $9 million[http://powergrid.thewrap.com/project/manhattan Box Office Information for ''Manhattan''.] ''[[The Wrap]]''. Retrieved April 4, 2013. | gross = $39.9 million{{cite web|url=http://boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=manhattan.htm|title=Box Office Information for Manhattan|publisher=[[Box Office Mojo]] |date= |accessdate=January 28, 2012}} }} '''''Manhattan''''' is a 1979 American [[romantic comedy]] film directed by [[Woody Allen]] and produced by [[Charles H. Joffe]]. The screenplay was written by Allen and [[Marshall Brickman]]. Allen co-stars as a twice-divorced 42-year-old comedy writer who dates a 17-year-old girl ([[Mariel Hemingway]]) but falls in love with his best friend's ([[Michael Murphy (actor)|Michael Murphy]]) mistress ([[Diane Keaton]]). [[Meryl Streep]] and [[Anne Byrne (actress)|Anne Byrne]] also star. ''Manhattan'' was filmed in [[black-and-white]] and [[Aspect ratio (image)#Previous and presently used aspect ratios|2.35:1 widescreen]]. The film features music composed by [[George Gershwin]], including ''[[Rhapsody in Blue]]'', which inspired the idea behind the film. Allen described the film as a combination of his previous two films, ''[[Annie Hall]]'' and ''[[Interiors]]''. The film was met with widespread critical acclaim and was nominated for two [[Academy Awards]]: [[Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress|Best Supporting Actress]] for Hemingway and [[Academy Award for Best Original Screenplay|Best Writing, Screenplay Written Directly for the Screen]] for Allen and Brickman. Its North American box-office receipts of $39.9 million made it Allen's second biggest box-office hit (after adjusting for inflation). Often considered one of Allen's best films,[https://movies.nytimes.com/person/79388/Woody-Allen/biography Woody Allen – Biography] by Jason Ankeny (Rovi), in ''[[The New York Times]]''[http://altscreen.com/01/22/2012/saturday-editors-pick-manhattan-1979/ Article] in ''[[New York (magazine)|New York]]'' by [[Bilge Ebiri]] on AFI Top 100 it ranks 46th on [[AFI's 100 Years...100 Laughs]] list and number 63 on [[Bravo (U.S. TV network)|Bravo's]] "100 Funniest Movies". In 2001, the United States [[Library of Congress]] deemed the film "culturally significant" and selected it for preservation in the [[National Film Registry]]. ==Plot== The film opens with a [[Montage (filmmaking)|montage]] of images of [[Manhattan]] and other parts of [[New York City]] accompanied by [[George Gershwin]]'s ''[[Rhapsody in Blue]]'', with Isaac Davis ([[Woody Allen]]) narrating drafts of an introduction to a book about a man who loves the city. Isaac is a twice-divorced, 42-year-old television comedy writer dealing with the women in his life who quits his unfulfilling job. He is dating Tracy ([[Mariel Hemingway]]), a 17-year-old girl attending the [[Dalton School]]. His best friend, college professor Yale Pollack ([[Michael Murphy (actor)|Michael Murphy]]), married to Emily (Anne Byrne), is having an affair with Mary Wilkie ([[Diane Keaton]]). Mary's ex-husband and former teacher, Jeremiah ([[Wallace Shawn]]), also appears, and Isaac's ex-wife Jill Davis ([[Meryl Streep]]) is writing a confessional book about their marriage. Jill has also since [[Coming out|come out of the closet]] as a [[lesbian]] and lives with her partner, Connie (Karen Ludwig). When Isaac meets Mary, her cultural snobbery rubs him the wrong way. Isaac runs into her again at an [[Equal Rights Amendment]] fund-raising event at the [[Museum of Modern Art]] hosted by [[Bella Abzug]] (playing herself) and accompanies her on a cab ride home. They chat until sunrise in a sequence that culminates in the iconic shot of the [[Queensboro Bridge]]. In spite of a growing attraction to Mary, Isaac continues his relationship with Tracy but emphasizes that theirs cannot be a serious relationship and encourages her to go to London to study acting. In another iconic scene, at Tracy's request, they go on a carriage ride through [[Central Park]]. After Yale breaks up with Mary, he suggests that Isaac ask her out. Isaac does, always having felt that Tracy was too young for him. Isaac breaks up with Tracy, much to her dismay, and before long, Mary has virtually moved into his apartment. Emily is curious about Isaac's new girlfriend. The two couples enjoy a day out and upon walking down a street Isaac spots Jill's new book ''Marriage, Divorce, and Selfhood''. Emily proceeds to read passages of the book, and even discusses an incident covered in the book of a [[Threesome|ménage à trois]] Isaac had with Jill and another woman, and an incident where Isaac attempted to run Connie over, much to Mary and Yale's amusement. Thoroughly humiliated, Isaac confronts Jill, who stoically responds about the book, and the film rights deal she has acquired. Upon returning home, Isaac learns from Mary that she is returning to Yale and wants to break up. A betrayed Isaac confronts Yale at the college where he teaches, and Yale argues that he found Mary first. Isaac responds by discussing Yale's extramarital affairs with Emily, but Yale told her that Isaac introduced Mary to him. In the [[dénouement]], Isaac lies on his sofa, musing into a tape recorder about the things that make "life worth living". When he finds himself saying "Tracy's face", he sets down the microphone. He leaves his apartment and sets out on foot for Tracy's. He arrives at the lobby of her family's apartment just as she is leaving for London. He says that she does not have to go and that he does not want "that thing about [her] that [he] like[s]" to change. She replies that the plans have already been made and reassures him that "not everybody gets corrupted" before saying "you have to have a little faith in people." He gives her a slight smile, with a final coy look to the camera then segueing into final shots of the skyline with some bars of ''Rhapsody in Blue'' playing again. An instrumental version of "[[Embraceable You]]" plays over the credits. ==Cast== * [[Woody Allen]] as Isaac Mortimer Davis * [[Diane Keaton]] as Mary Wilkie * [[Michael Murphy (actor)|Michael Murphy]] as Yale Pollack * [[Mariel Hemingway]] as Tracy * [[Meryl Streep]] as Jill Davis * [[Anne Byrne (actress)|Anne Byrne]] {{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0126117/bio|title=Anne Byrne Hoffman|website=IMDb}} as Emily Pollack * [[Michael O'Donoghue]] as Dennis * [[Wallace Shawn]] as Jeremiah (His film debut) * Karen Ludwig {{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0525023/|title=Karen Ludwig|website=IMDb}} as Connie * [[Charles Levin (actor)|Charles Levin]], [[Karen Allen]], and [[David Rasche]] as Television actors * [[Mark Linn-Baker]] and [[Frances Conroy]] as Shakespearean actors ==Production== ===Development=== According to Allen, the idea for ''Manhattan'' originated from his love of [[George Gershwin]]'s music. He was listening to one of the composer's albums of overtures and thought, "this would be a beautiful thing to make ... a movie in black and white ... a romantic movie".{{harvnb|Fox|1996|p=}}{{page needed|date=July 2012}} Allen has said that ''Manhattan'' was "like a mixture of what I was trying to do with ''[[Annie Hall]]'' and ''[[Interiors]].''"{{harvnb|Brode|1987|p=}}{{page needed|date=July 2012}} He also said that his film deals with the problem of people trying to live a decent existence in an essentially junk-obsessed contemporary culture without selling out, admitting that he himself could conceive of giving away all of his "possessions to charity and living in much more modest circumstances," and adding that he has "rationalized [his] way out of it so far, but [he] could conceive of doing it."{{cite news | last = Rich | first = Frank | title = An Interview with Woody |work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]| date = April 30, 1979}} According to actress [[Stacey Nelkin]], ''Manhattan'' was based on her romantic relationship with Woody Allen. Her bit part in ''Annie Hall'' ended up on the cutting-room floor, and their relationship started when she was 17 years old and a student at New York’s [[Stuyvesant High School]].{{cite web|url=http://www.howardstern.com/rundown.hs?j=n&d=1302062400|title=Stacey Nelkin: Actress, Sexpert – ''The Howard Stern Show'' for April 7, 2011|date=April 7, 2011}} Allen did not publicly acknowledge the relationship until 2014.{{cite news|last=Allen|first=Woody|title=Woody Allen Speaks Out|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/02/09/opinion/sunday/woody-allen-speaks-out.html?hp&rref=opinion&_r=0|accessdate=Feb 13, 2014|newspaper=New York Times|date=Feb 7, 2014}} ===Filming=== Allen talked to cinematographer [[Gordon Willis]] about how fun it would be to shoot the film in [[Black-and-white|black and white]], [[Panavision]] [[Aspect ratio (image)|aspect ratio]] (2.35:1) because it would give "a great look at New York City, which is sort of one of the characters in the film".{{harvnb|Bjorkman |1995|p=108}} Allen decided to shoot his film in black and white because that was how he remembered it from when he was small. "Maybe it's a reminiscence from old photographs, films, books and all that. But that's how I remember New York." He always heard Gershwin music with it, too. In ''Manhattan'' he really thinks that he and Willis succeeded in showing the city. "When seeing it there on that big screen, it's really decadent".{{harvnb|Palmer|1980|p=112}} The picture was shot on location with the exception of some of the scenes in the planetarium which were filmed on a set.{{harvnb|Bjorkman |1995|p=112}} [[File:woody allen manhattan.jpg|thumb|The bridge shot]] The famous bridge shot was done at five in the morning.{{cite news|last=Willis|first=Gordon|title=Made in ''Manhattan''|work=Moviemaker|pages=|publisher=|date=April 6, 2004|url=http://www.moviemaker.com/magazine/issues/54/manhattan.html|accessdate=December 5, 2014}} The production had to bring their own bench as there were no park benches at the location.{{cite video|people=Weide, Robert B. (Director)|year=2011|title=Woody Allen: A Documentary|medium=Television|publisher=[[PBS]]}} The bridge had two sets of necklace lights on a timer controlled by the city. When the sun came up, the bridge lights went off. Willis made arrangements with the city to leave the lights on and that he would let them know when they got the shot. Afterwards, they could be turned off. As they started to shoot the scene, one string of bridge lights went out, and Allen was forced to use that take. After finishing the film, Allen was very unhappy with it and asked United Artists not to release it. He offered to make a film for free instead.{{harvnb|Bjorkman |1995|p=126}} He later said: "I just thought to myself, 'At this point in my life, if this is the best I can do, they shouldn't give me money to make movies.'" ===Music=== {{see also|Manhattan (soundtrack)}} All titles of the soundtrack were compositions by George Gershwin. They were performed by the [[New York Philharmonic]] under [[Zubin Mehta]] and the [[Buffalo Philharmonic Orchestra|Buffalo Philharmonic]] under [[Michael Tilson Thomas]]. * New York Philharmonic ** ''[[Rhapsody in Blue]]'' ** "[[Love is Sweeping the Country]]" ** "Land of the Gay Caballero" ** "Sweet and Low Down" ** "[[I've Got a Crush on You]]" ** "Do-Do-Do" ** "[['S Wonderful]]" ** "[[Oh, Lady Be Good!]]" ** "[[Strike Up the Band (song)|Strike Up the Band]]" ** "[[Embraceable You]]" * Buffalo Philharmonic ** "[[Someone to Watch Over Me (song)|Someone to Watch Over Me]]" ** "[[He Loves and She Loves]]" ** "[[But Not for Me (song)|But Not for Me]]" A part of the first [[Movement (music)|movement]] of Mozart's [[Symphony No. 40 (Mozart)|Symphony No. 40]] is heard in a concert scene. ==Reaction== ===Box office=== ''Manhattan'' opened in 29 North American theaters on April 25, 1979. It grossed $485,734 ($16,749 per screen) in its opening weekend and earned $39.9 million in its entire run,{{cite news |title=''Manhattan'' |publisher=Box Office Mojo | date =May 2, 1979 |url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=manhattan.htm|accessdate=January 11, 2007}} making the film the [[1979 in film|17th highest-grossing picture of the year]]. The film was shown out of competition at the [[1979 Cannes Film Festival]] in May.{{cite web|url=http://www.festival-cannes.com/en/archives/ficheFilm/id/1894/year/1979.html |title=Festival de Cannes: Manhattan |accessdate=May 25, 2009 |work=festival-cannes.com |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120118191400/http://www.festival-cannes.com/en/archives/ficheFilm/id/1894/year/1979.html |archivedate=January 18, 2012 |df= }} Adjusted for ticket price inflation (as of 2017), ''Manhattan'' grossed $141,484,800, making it Allen's second biggest box-office hit, following 1977's ''[[Annie Hall]]''.{{cite web |url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/people/chart/?view=Director&id=woodallen.htm |title=Woody Allen Movie Box Office Results |work=Box Office Mojo |accessdate=2017-09-28}} ===Critical response=== The film received largely positive reviews and currently holds a rating of 95% "Certified Fresh" on [[Rotten Tomatoes]] based on reviews from 59 critics.{{cite news|title=''Manhattan''|publisher=Rotten Tomatoes|date=May 2, 1979|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/manhattan/|accessdate=May 27, 2009}} Gary Arnold, in ''[[The Washington Post]]'', wrote: "''Manhattan'' has comic integrity in part because Allen is now making jokes at the expense of his own [[parochialism]]. There's no opportunity to heap condescending abuse on the phonies and sellouts decorating the Hollywood landscape. The result appears to be a more authentic and magnanimous comic perception of human vanity and foolhardiness."{{cite news|last=Arnold|first=Gary|title=Woody Allen's Comic High: A Delightful and Deluxe Rhapsody of Wry Romance|work=[[The Washington Post]]|date =May 2, 1979}} In his review for ''[[Newsweek]]'' magazine, Jack Kroll wrote: "Allen's growth in every department is lovely to behold. He gets excellent performances from his cast. The increasing visual beauty of his films is part of their grace and sweetness, their balance between Allen's yearning romanticism and his tough eye for the fatuous and sentimental – a balance also expressed in his best screen play [''sic''] yet."{{cite news|last=Kroll|first=Jack|title=Woody's Big Apple|work=[[Newsweek]]|date=April 30, 1979}} In his review for the ''[[Chicago Sun-Times]]'', [[Roger Ebert]], who gave the film three-and-a-half stars out of four, wrote, "Diane Keaton gives us a fresh and nicely edged New York intellectual. And [[Mariel Hemingway]] deserves some kind of special award for what's in some ways the most difficult role in the film."{{cite news|last=Ebert|first=Roger|authorlink=Roger Ebert|title= ''Manhattan''|work=[[Chicago Sun-Times]]|date=January 1, 1979 |url=http://rogerebert.suntimes.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/19790101/REVIEWS/901010322/1023|accessdate=January 11, 2008}} Ebert included the film in his list of ''[[The Great Movies]]''.{{cite web|first=Roger|last=Ebert|date=March 18, 2001|url=http://rogerebert.suntimes.com/apps/pbcs.dll/section?category=greatmovies_fulllist|title=Great Movies|work=Sun-Times}} [[Gene Siskel]] of the ''[[Chicago Tribune]]'' awarded a full four out of four stars, calling it "a remarkable motion picture. 'Manhattan' may turn out to be the year's best comedy ''and'' drama."[[Gene Siskel|Siskel, Gene]] (May 11, 1979). "Comedy, drama have a good relationship in Allen film". ''[[Chicago Tribune]]''. Section 3, p. 1. [[Vincent Canby]] of ''[[The New York Times]]'' called the film "extraordinarily fine and funny" with "superb" performances from Keaton and Hemingway.[[Vincent Canby|Canby, Vincent]] (April 25, 1979). "The Screen: Woody Allen's 'Manhattan'". ''[[The New York Times]]''. C17. [[Charles Chaplin]] of the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' called it "harder, harsher, crueler, deeper-going, more assertive but in the end no less life-affirming than 'Annie Hall,'" and declared ''Manhattan'' "even better" than that film.[[Charles Champlin|Champlin, Charles]] (April 22, 1979). "'Manhattan': Allen's Dark Comic View". ''[[Los Angeles Times]]''. Calendar, p. 1. [[Alexander Walker (critic)|Alexander Walker]] of the ''[[London Evening Standard]]'' wrote: "So precisely nuanced is the speech, so subtle the behaviour of a group of friends, lovers, mistresses and cuckolds who keep splitting up and pairing off like unstable molecules".{{harvnb|Palmer|1980|p=114}} In 2007, [[J. Hoberman]] wrote in ''[[The Village Voice]]'': "The New York City that Woody so tediously defended in ''[[Annie Hall]]'' was in crisis. And so he imagined an improved version. More than that, he cast this shining city in the form of those movies that he might have seen as a child in Coney Island—freeing the visions that he sensed to be locked up in the silver screen."{{cite news|last=Hoberman |first=J |title=Defending ''Manhattan'' |work=[[The Village Voice]] |date=July 10, 2007 |url=http://www.villagevoice.com/film/0728,hoberman,77195,20.html |accessdate=July 11, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070714020940/http://www.villagevoice.com/film/0728%2Choberman%2C77195%2C20.html |archivedate=July 14, 2007 |df= }} In October 2013, readers of ''[[The Guardian]]'' newspaper voted it the best film directed by Woody Allen.{{cite news|title=The 10 best Woody Allen films|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2013/oct/04/the-10-best-woody-allen-films|accessdate=November 22, 2014|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=October 4, 2013}} ===Accolades=== [[New York Film Critics Circle]] named Allen best director for ''Manhattan''.{{cite news |title= ''Kramer vs. Kramer'' selected best film |work=[[The Globe and Mail]] | date =December 21, 1979}} The [[National Society of Film Critics]] also named Allen best director along with [[Robert Benton]], who directed ''[[Kramer vs. Kramer]]''.{{cite news |last=Arnold |first=Gary | title = Film Critics' Pick of the Year |work=[[The Washington Post]] | date =January 3, 1980}} The film was nominated for [[Academy Awards]] for [[Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress|Best Supporting Actress]] (Mariel Hemingway) and [[Academy Award for Best Original Screenplay|Best Original Screenplay]] (Allen and [[Marshall Brickman]]).{{cite news | last = Arnold | first = Gary | coauthors = | title = ''Kramer'', ''Jazz'' Lead Nominees |work=[[The Washington Post]] |date=February 26, 1980}} It also won the [[BAFTA Award for Best Film]]. In ''[[Empire (film magazine)|Empire]]'' magazine's 2008 poll of the 500 greatest movies ever made, ''Manhattan'' was ranked number 76.{{cite web |url=http://www.empireonline.com/500/84.asp |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121021180659/http://www.empireonline.com/500/84.asp |archivedate=2012-10-21 |title=Empire's 500 Greatest Movies of All Time |website=Empire |deadurl=yes |df= }} The film was number 63 on [[Bravo (US TV network)|Bravo's]] "100 Funniest Movies". In 2001, the United States [[Library of Congress]] deemed it "culturally significant" and selected it for preservation in the [[National Film Registry]]. It is also ranked #4 on [[Rotten Tomatoes]]' 25 Best Romantic Comedies.{{cite web | title = 25 Best Romantic Comedies |work = [[Rotten Tomatoes]] |year = 2009 | url = http://www.rottentomatoes.com/guides/best_romantic_comedies/manhattan/ | accessdate = February 12, 2009}} The film is recognized by [[American Film Institute]] in these lists: * 1998: [[AFI's 100 Years...100 Movies]] – Nominated{{cite web|url=http://www.afi.com/Docs/100Years/movies400.pdf |title=AFI's 100 Years...100 Movies Nominees |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2016-08-06}} * 2000: [[AFI's 100 Years...100 Laughs]] – #46{{cite web|last= |first= |title=AFI's 100 Years...100 Laughs |url=http://www.afi.com/Docs/100Years/laughs100.pdf |publisher=[[American Film Institute]] |date= |accessdate=2016-08-06}} * 2002: [[AFI's 100 Years...100 Passions]] – #66{{cite web|last= |first= |title=AFI's 100 Years...100 Passions |url=http://www.afi.com/Docs/100Years/passions100.pdf |publisher=[[American Film Institute]] |date= |accessdate=2016-08-06}} * 2005: [[AFI's 100 Years...100 Movie Quotes]]: ** Isaac Davis: "I think people should mate for life, like pigeons or Catholics." – Nominated{{cite web|url=http://www.afi.com/Docs/100Years/quotes400.pdf |title=AFI's 100 Years...100 Movie Quotes Nominees |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2016-08-06}} * 2007: [[AFI's 100 Years...100 Movies (10th Anniversary Edition)]] – Nominated{{cite web|url=http://www.afi.com/Docs/100YearsMovies_ballot_06.pdf |title=AFI's 100 Years...100 Movies Nominees (10th Anniversary Edition) |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2016-08-06}} ==Home release== Allen wanted to preserve Willis's [[Composition (visual arts)|composition]]s and insisted that the aspect ratio be preserved when the film was released on video (an unusual request in a time when widescreen films were normally [[pan and scan|panned and scanned]] for TV and video release). As a result, all copies of the film on video (and most television broadcasts) were [[letterbox]]ed, originally with a gray border. ''Manhattan'' was first released on [[Blu-ray Disc|Blu-ray]] on January 24, 2012, alongside Allen's 1977 film ''Annie Hall''.{{cite web|last=Nashawaty|first=Chris|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,20562561,00.html|title=''Annie Hall'' Review|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|date=January 24, 2012|accessdate=July 19, 2012}} Both releases included the films' original theatrical trailer. ==Legacy== In her memoir ''Out Came the Sun'' (2015), Hemingway detailed Allen's visit to her family home in [[Ketchum, Idaho]] upon completion of filming. After intimating that he wanted to take her to [[Paris]], Hemingway warned her parents “that I didn’t know what the arrangement was going to be, that I wasn’t sure if I was even going to have my own room. Woody hadn’t said that. He hadn’t even hinted it. But I wanted them to put their foot down. They didn’t. They kept lightly encouraging me.” When Hemingway stipulated the procurement of a separate hotel room, Allen "called for his private jet the next morning and left Idaho."http://www.foxnews.com/entertainment/2015/03/25/exclusive-young-mariel-hemingway-had-to-rebuff-woody-allens-advances.htmlhttps://www.vanityfair.com/hollywood/2015/03/woody-allen-mariel-hemingway-manhattan Following publication of the anecdote, conservative [[pundit]] and film critic [[John Podhoretz]] characterized Allen as a "repugnant [[ephebophile]]" on [[Twitter]].https://twitter.com/jpodhoretz/status/580660744385130496 ''Manhattan''{{'}}s screenplay was performed in front of a live audience at the [[Los Angeles County Museum of Art]] on November 15, 2012, as part of [[Jason Reitman]]'s Live Read series. Actors read the script, narrowed to six speaking parts, and still photographs from the movie were projected behind them.[http://insidemovies.ew.com/2012/11/09/jason-reitman-woody-allen-manhattan-live-read/ "Jason Reitman to re-create Woody Allen's ''Manhattan'' in live-read event"] by Anthony Breznican, ''Entertainment Weekly'', November 9, 2012. Retrieved August 31, 2013. The cast included [http://www.woodyallenpages.com/2012/11/jason-reitman-to-live-read-manhattan-in-l-a/ "Jason Reitman to Live Read ''Manhattan'' in L.A."], ''The Woody Allen Pages'', November 10, 2012. Retrieved August 31, 2013.[http://www.woodyallenpages.com/2012/11/stephen-merchant-and-olivia-munn-starred-in-jason-reitmans-manhattan-live-read/ "Stephen Merchant and Olivia Munn Starred in Jason Reitman's ''Manhattan'' Live Read"], The Woody Allen Pages, November 18, 2012. Retrieved August 31, 2013. [[Stephen Merchant]] as Isaac Davis, [[Olivia Munn]] as Mary Wilkie, [[Shailene Woodley]] as Tracy, [[Michael Murphy (actor)|Michael Murphy]] as Yale Pollack, [[Mae Whitman]] as Emily Pollack, [[Erika Christensen]] as Jill Davis and [[Jason Mantzoukas]] as Dennis. In keeping with the project's focus on impermanence and spontaneity, there were no rehearsals, shows were announced only days prior, and the names of some cast members were withheld entirely; performances were not recorded.[http://articles.latimes.com/2012/jan/19/entertainment/la-et-guidefeature19-20120119 "Jason Reitman Brings Memorable Movies to Life at LACMA"], by Katherine Tulich. ''The Los Angeles Times'', January 19, 2012. Retrieved August 31, 2013. ''Manhattan'' inspired the song "Remember Manhattan" written by [[Richard Marx]] and [[Fee Waybill]] from Marx's [[Richard Marx (album)|debut]] album. ==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}} |isbn=0-571-17335-7 |ref=harv}} *{{cite book|last=Brode|first=Douglas|title=Woody Allen: His Films and Career |year=1987 |edition= |publisher=Citadel Press |location= |isbn= |ref=harv}} *{{cite {{Infobox book | name = More-with-Less Cookbook | orig title = | translator = | image = Doris Janzen Longacre - More-With-Less Cookbook.jpeg | author = Doris Janzen Longacre | cover_artist = | country = | language = English | series = | subject = | genre = [[Cookbook]] | publisher = Herald Press | release_date = 1976 | media_type = | pages = | size_weight = | isbn = 0-8361-9103-X |isbn_note= (spiral edition), 0-8361-9263-X (paperback edition) | oclc= }}
The '''''More-with-Less Cookbook''''' is a [[cookbook]] commissioned by [[Mennonite Central Committee]] in 1976 with the goal of "helping [[Christians]] respond in a caring-sharing way in a world with limited [[food|food resources]]"<ref>Longacre, Doris Janzen: ''More-with-Less Cookbook (25th Anniversary Edition)'', page 7. Herald Press, 2000.</ref> and "to challenge North Americans to consume less so others could eat enough".<ref name="Mennonite Central Committee">{{cite web| url=http://www.worldcommunitycookbook.org/more/about.html | title=More-with-Less -Earmarks of a bestseller| accessdate=2009-11-11 }}</ref> The first edition of the book has received forty-seven printings, with over 847,000 copies sold worldwide, including [[Bantam Press]], [[British English]] and German editions.<ref>Longacre, Doris Janzen: ''More-with-Less Cookbook (25th Anniversary Edition)''. Herald Press, 2000.</ref>
The book advocates the consumption of more [[whole grains]], [[legumes]], [[fruits]], [[vegetables]], [[Nut (fruit)|nuts]] and [[seeds]], the moderation of [[meat]] and [[dairy products]] and the avoidance of [[processed food|processed]] and [[convenience foods]]. The recipes, collected from [[Mennonite]] and other [[Christian]] families around the world, are intended to be affordable, [[nutrition|nutritious]] and socially and [[ecology|ecologically]] responsible.
A new 40th anniversary edition of the book is planned for 2016 publication.<ref>MennoMedia, [http://www.mennomedia.org/?Page=8134 "More-with-Less: Changing the world, one recipe at a time"], ''MennoMedia'', March 11, 2015. Retrieved 2015-06-29.</ref>
== See also == *[[Simple living]]
==References== {{reflist}} *Martin, Pat Hostetter. "[http://www.gameo.org/encyclopedia/contents/L666.html Longacre, Doris Janzen (1940-1979)]." [[Global Anabaptist Mennonite Encyclopedia Online]]. 1987. Retrieved 11 November 2009
[[Category:1976 books]] [[Category:2000 books]] [[Category:Cookbooks]] [[Category:Mennonitism]]

revision.text:
{{ref-improve|date=February 2016}} {{update|260,000 articles as of June 2005 - a little more than 10 years ago.|date=August 2015}} {{Infobox book | name = Nationalencyklopedin [[File:Nationalencyklopedin logo.svg]] | image = Nationalencyklopedin.jpg | caption = Volumes 1–10 of 20, 1989–1996 | author = | country = Sweden | language = [[Swedish language|Swedish]] | subject = General | genre = [[Reference work|Reference]] [[encyclopedia]] | publisher = | release_date = | media_type = | isbn = | oclc = 185256473 }} '''''Nationalencyklopedin''''' ({{IPA-sv|natɧʊ²nɑːlɛnsʏklʊpɛˌdiːn|lang}}), abbreviated '''NE''', is a comprehensive contemporary [[Swedish language|Swedish-language]] [[encyclopedia]], initiated by a favourable loan from the [[Government of Sweden]] of 17 million [[Swedish krona|Swedish kronor]] in 1980, which was repaid by December 1990.<ref>[http://uppslag.psilander.se/ne.htm Svenska uppslagsverk: Nationalencyklopedin], accessed on July 22, 2009 {{sv icon}}</ref> The printed version consists of 20 volumes with 172,000 articles; the [[Internet]] version comprises 260,000 articles (as of June 2005).
==History== The project was born in 1980, when a government committee suggested that negotiations be initiated with various [[publisher]]s. This stage was finished in August 1985, when {{ill|Bra Böcker|sv}} in [[Höganäs]] became the publisher responsible for the project. The project specifications were for a modern reference work based on a [[science|scientific]] [[paradigm]] incorporating [[gender]] and [[natural environment|environment]]al issues.
Pre-orders for the work were unprecedented; before the first volume was published in December 1989, 54,000 customers had ordered the encyclopedia. The last volume came out in 1996, with three supplemental volumes in 2000.
Associated with the ''Nationalencyklopedin'' project are also: *''NE:s Ordbok'', a [[dictionary]] in three volumes (1995–1996) *''NE:s Årsband'', complementary volumes concerning current events and fast changing information distributed annually since 1997 *''NE:s Sverigeatlas'', an atlas of [[Sweden]] (1998) *''NE:s Världsatlas'', a world atlas (1998) *''NE-spelet'', a quiz game with 8,000 questions (1999)
In 1997, the first [[Digital data|digital]] form of the encyclopedia was released on 6 [[CD-ROM]]s (later on [[DVD]] as well), and in 2000 as an [[Internet]] [[subscription]] service. The online version contains the dictionary as well as an updated version of the original encyclopedia. It has 356,000 entries, 183,000 of which are encyclopedic articles. The service has been completed with several features not available in the printed version, such as a Swedish–English dictionary.
==See also== *''[[Nordisk familjebok]]'' (1876–1957) *[[Swedish Wikipedia]] *[[List of online encyclopedias]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.ne.se/ ''Nationalencyklopedin''] - Official site (in Swedish) *[http://uppslag.psilander.se/ne.htm ''Svenska uppslagsverk''] - Christofer Psilander's comprehensive bibliography on Swedish encyclopedias
[[Category:Swedish encyclopedias]] [[Category:National encyclopedias]] [[Category:Online encyclopedias]] [[Category:1989 books]] [[Category:20th-century encyclopedias]] [[Category:21st-century encyclopedias]]
